title: Kochi Rajya Prajamandalam
text:
Kochi Rajya Prajamandalam is a political party which was formed in 1941 at <a href="Thrissur">Thrissur</a>, <a href="Kerala">Kerala</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, in connection with the <a href="Indian%20independence%20movement">Indian independence movement</a>. <a href="E.%20Ikkanda%20Warrier">E. Ikkanda Warrier</a>, <a href="V.%20R.%20Krishnan%20Ezhuthachan">V. R. Krishnan Ezhuthachan</a>, S. Neelakanda Iyer, and <a href="Kurur%20Neelakandan%20Namboodiripad">Kurur Neelakandan Namboodiripad</a> were the key people in the formation of the party. Eminent politicians like <a href="Panampilly%20Govinda%20Menon">Panampilly Govinda Menon</a>, <a href="K.%20Karunakaran">K. Karunakaran</a> worked in the party.
History.
A group of young people who were displeased with the functioning of political movements in the erstwhile <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Cochin">Kochi state</a>, at the meeting held on 26 January 1941 under the leadership of <a href="V.%20R.%20Krishnan%20Ezhuthachan">V. R. Krishnan Ezhuthachan</a>, decided to form the Kochi Rajya Prajamandalam.
The party was formally inaugurated on 9 February 1941 at Manikandanalthara, <a href="Thrissur">Thrissur</a> and selected S. Neelakanda Iyer as President and Ezhuthachan as general secretary. The primary objective of party was to end political <a href="sovereignty">sovereignty</a> of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Cochin">King of Cochin</a> and gain equality and political power for the people. The party also worked to spread the use of <a href="khadi">khadi</a>, prohibit <a href="liquor">liquor</a>, and gain progress in the field of <a href="Education%20in%20India">education</a>.
Prajamandalam's work to save people from calamity during the flood of 1941 gained acceptance for the party. The party formed a flood relief committee during that time.
Prajamandalam formed an organisation called which worked primarily to end the difficulties farmers faced due to <a href="feudalism">feudalism</a>. stood for permanent ownership for farmers in their field. Their protests caused acceptance of the bill on 13 February 1943 at the <a href="Cochin%20Legislative%20Council">Cochin Legislative Council</a>.
Prajamandalam decided to conduct its first annual meeting in 1942 at <a href="Irinjalakkuda">Irinjalakkuda</a>, but the <a href="Dewan">diwan</a> of Cochin, A. F. W. Dixon, banned it. However, some leaders came forward to conduct the meeting. Many leaders including <a href="K.%20Karunakaran">Karunakaran</a> were arrested and faced brutal torture in jail.
In connection with the <a href="Quit%20India%20movement">Quit India movement</a> on 5 August 1942, a conference was conducted under the leadership of <a href="Gandhiji">Gandhiji</a> and <a href="Nehru">Nehru</a> for <a href="All%20India%20Congress%20Committee">All India Congress Committee</a> at <a href="Bombay">Bombay</a>. Iyer and Ezhuthachan attended the conference by representing Prajamandalam. As part of the Quit India movement, Prajamandalam actively participated in <a href="strike%20action">strikes</a>. During that time there was strong ban in functioning of the press, Prajamandalam started a newspaper called "<a href="Deenabandhu">Deenabandhu</a>." The newspaper helped to strengthen freedom movements.
In 1945 Prajamandalam faced election and gained a majority in the Cochin Legislative Council. Prajamandalam chose opposition and worked for responsible government. The party also worked for the <a href="Temple%20Entry%20Proclamation">Temple Entry movement</a> also.
Prajamandalam is one of the first political parties which dispersed after completion of its objective. Later Prajamandalam merged with <a href="Indian%20national%20congress">Indian National Congress</a>.
